answers.author: John Garvison
answers.text:
While I was an elected County Auditor, I had records both paper, and microfiche dating back to the 1850's. I had newspapers that were bound but were crumbling back to the early 1900's. We digitized all of these records approximately 1 million records. We contracted with a vendor Aptitude Solutions as part of our upgrade to a new recording software management system. It took about 11 months for the conversion, but it was well worht it. Once we digitized all of the records, we handed all of the records older than 20 years to our Washington Secretary of State's Archives division. 
They were able to safeguard the original documents and we had digitized images for people to review and look at.
You must get a vendor you trust, even if they are the high bidder, in digitizing, we found there are a lot of fly-by night operations out there. Server space was a problem, take whatever you think and your vendor thinks will be your server space necessary and triple it. Trust me you will thank me on this.
Good luck!

author: Andy White
text:
......specifically 120 years of an local newpaper.
We have our local paper back to the 1880s on microfilm.  Half of this collection is on acetate film.
From the Durango Public Library:
Our Board and the newpserpaper itself is interested in funding the digitization of the paper before the acetate film self destructs.
Has anyone else attacked a challenge like this and could share some must do's and must avoids?
We are wondering about a server service rather than trying to buy one to store here at the Library,  seeking a great digitization service, etc.
title: Digitization of Old Records
